categories.title: Hyperfy Development: Technical Updates, Troubleshooting, and Community Feedback

content.text: The Hyperfy community engaged in a series of technical discussions and problem-solving sessions across multiple areas of development. Key topics included raycasting behavior, rigidbody tagging, UI improvements, authentication flows, and asset optimization.

Raycasting and Rigidbody Tagging: Developers clarified that for raycasting to detect objects, tags must be applied to the rigidbody parent, not individual colliders. This behavior is consistent across apps. Examples and fixes were shared to resolve issues where raycast tag detection returned null.

Cross-App Raycasting and Pointer Events: ashxn.eth confirmed that raycasting works identically across apps and is working on a demo. Pointer events like onPointerEnter/Down/Up can be applied to visual nodes such as meshes, enabling interactive UI elements.

Authentication and Deployment: Developers explored iframe-based authentication and session cookies. A proposed addition to Apps.js (world.getQueryParams()) would allow reading URL parameters natively. Fly.io deployment was confirmed to preserve world files when using [[mounts]].

UI and Controller Enhancements: Suggestions included adding a UI slider for corner rounding and improving label formatting. Discussions also covered the limitations of using PhysX controllers for movement and tagging, with potential improvements under consideration.

GIF Performance and Media Optimization: GIFs were reported to perform poorly in Hyperfy V1, especially at high resolutions. Developers recommended converting GIFs to MP4 videos for better performance, particularly in VR and mobile environments. A built-in GIF-to-video conversion tool was suggested.

AI-Assisted Game Creation: Community members encouraged non-technical users to explore game creation in Hyperfy V2 using AI. They recommended starting with app.configure and using existing code examples. Documentation improvements were requested to support this workflow.

Marketing and Community Engagement: Feedback was given to increase posting frequency on X (Twitter) to boost visibility. Suggestions included daily updates, community call summaries, and improved branding asset visibility. Limited team bandwidth was cited as a challenge.

Material Rendering in Blender: A discussion clarified that Blender materials are double-sided by default. To ensure single-sided rendering in Hyperfy, users must enable 'Backface Culling' in Blender’s material settings. This behavior applies to Blender versions 4.3 and 4.4.

Asset Libraries and Exporting: Users requested a centralized library of .hyp objects. Community members shared links to a Discord thread and the Hyperworld marketplace. Additionally, a custom batch exporter for Blender models is being developed to overcome limitations in Hyperfy’s default tools.

categories.title: Hyperfy Development Updates and Community Discussions

content.text: The Hyperfy community has been actively discussing a wide range of technical topics, feature requests, and development workflows. Key areas of focus include raycasting behavior, model exporting, authentication, UI improvements, and performance optimization.

Raycasting and Rigidbody tagging were clarified: tags must be applied to the Rigidbody parent, not individual colliders, for detection to work. Cross-app raycasting behaves the same as in-app. Pointer events like onPointerEnter/Down/Up are supported on visual nodes such as meshes.
Model exporting limitations in Hyperfy led to the development of a custom batch exporter for Blender by .somethingmoreprofessional. Documentation updates are planned to support this workflow.

Authentication via iframe and URL parameters was discussed. While not natively supported, session cookies and external APIs are viable workarounds. A proposal to add world.getQueryParams() to Apps.js was suggested to streamline this process.

Controller vs Rigidbody usage was debated. Controllers, similar to Unity’s CharacterController, have limited tag and contact support due to PhysX constraints. This affects how developers implement movement and interaction logic.
UI improvements were proposed, including a slider for corner rounding and label formatting consistency. A PR was accepted to clean up UI inconsistencies.

GIF performance in Hyperfy V1 was flagged as problematic, especially for large files. Developers recommended converting GIFs to MP4 videos for better performance, particularly in VR and mobile environments.
A bug in survey forms where optional fields were marked as required was reported and quickly fixed. This highlights the community’s responsiveness to UX issues.

Community engagement and marketing were discussed. Suggestions included increasing posting frequency on X (Twitter) and sharing community call summaries. Limited team bandwidth was cited as a challenge.

AI-assisted game creation in Hyperfy V2 was encouraged. Non-technical users were advised to use app.configure and reference existing nodes. Documentation improvements are underway to support this use case.

Material rendering behavior in Blender exports was clarified. By default, Blender materials are double-sided unless 'Backface Culling' is enabled. This setting affects how meshes appear in Hyperfy and should be documented for asset creators.
A request for a centralized .hyp object library was addressed with links to a Discord thread and the Hyperworld marketplace, providing reusable assets for developers.

The Qwen2.5-Omni-7B model was briefly discussed. It is a multi-modal model hosted on Hugging Face, and users are awaiting its availability on Ollama for local deployment. No implementation steps were taken yet.
Token distribution transparency was addressed with a link to https://token.hyperfy.xyz, confirming that top wallets are DAO and team-vested.
